00020 void
00021 pinit(void)
00022 {
00023   initlock(&ptable.lock, "ptable");
00024 }

00026 // Print a process listing to console.  For debugging.
00027 // Runs when user types ^P on console.
00028 // No lock to avoid wedging a stuck machine further.
00029 void
00030 procdump(void)
00031 {
00032   static char *states[] = {
00033   [UNUSED]    "unused",
00034   [EMBRYO]    "embryo",
00035   [SLEEPING]  "sleep ",
00036   [RUNNABLE]  "runble",
00037   [RUNNING]   "run   ",
00038   [ZOMBIE]    "zombie"
00039   };
00040   int i;
00041   struct proc *p;
00042   char *state;
00043   uint pc[10];
00044   
00045   for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++){
00046     if(p->state == UNUSED)
00047       continue;
00048     if(p->state >= 0 && p->state < NELEM(states) && states[p->state])
00049       state = states[p->state];
00050     else
00051       state = "???";
00052     cprintf("%d %s %s", p->pid, state, p->name);
00053     if(p->state == SLEEPING){
00054       getcallerpcs((uint*)p->context->ebp+2, pc);
00055       for(i=0; i<10 && pc[i] != 0; i++)
00056         cprintf(" %p", pc[i]);
00057     }
00058     cprintf("\n");
00059   }
00060 }
00061 
00062 // Set up CPU's kernel segment descriptors.
00063 // Run once at boot time on each CPU.
00064 void
00065 ksegment(void)
00066 {
00067   struct cpu *c;
00068 
00069   c = &cpus[cpunum()];
00070   c->gdt[SEG_KCODE] = SEG(STA_X|STA_R, 0, 0x100000 + 64*1024-1, 0);
00071   c->gdt[SEG_KDATA] = SEG(STA_W, 0, 0xffffffff, 0);
00072   c->gdt[SEG_KCPU] = SEG(STA_W, &c->cpu, 8, 0);
00073   lgdt(c->gdt, sizeof(c->gdt));
00074   loadgs(SEG_KCPU << 3);
00075   
00076   // Initialize cpu-local storage.
00077   cpu = c;
00078   proc = 0;
00079 }
00080 
00081 // Set up CPU's segment descriptors and current process task state.
00082 void
00083 usegment(void)
00084 {
00085   pushcli();
00086   cpu->gdt[SEG_UCODE] = SEG(STA_X|STA_R, proc->mem, proc->sz-1, DPL_USER);
00087   cpu->gdt[SEG_UDATA] = SEG(STA_W, proc->mem, proc->sz-1, DPL_USER);
00088   cpu->gdt[SEG_TSS] = SEG16(STS_T32A, &cpu->ts, sizeof(cpu->ts)-1, 0);
00089   cpu->gdt[SEG_TSS].s = 0;
00090   cpu->ts.ss0 = SEG_KDATA << 3;
00091   cpu->ts.esp0 = (uint)proc->kstack + KSTACKSIZE;
00092   ltr(SEG_TSS << 3);
00093   popcli();
00094 }
00095 
00096 // Look in the process table for an UNUSED proc.
00097 // If found, change state to EMBRYO and return it.
00098 // Otherwise return 0.
00099 static struct proc*
00100 allocproc(void)
00101 {
00102   struct proc *p;
00103   char *sp;
00104 
00105   acquire(&ptable.lock);
00106   for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++)
00107     if(p->state == UNUSED)
00108       goto found;
00109   release(&ptable.lock);
00110   return 0;
00111 
00112 found:
00113   p->state = EMBRYO;
00114   p->pid = nextpid++;
00115   release(&ptable.lock);
00116 
00117   // Allocate kernel stack if necessary.
00118   if((p->kstack = kalloc(KSTACKSIZE)) == 0){
00119     p->state = UNUSED;
00120     return 0;
00121   }
00122   sp = p->kstack + KSTACKSIZE;
00123   
00124   // Leave room for trap frame.
00125   sp -= sizeof *p->tf;
00126   p->tf = (struct trapframe*)sp;
00127   
00128   // Set up new context to start executing at forkret,
00129   // which returns to trapret (see below).
00130   sp -= 4;
00131   *(uint*)sp = (uint)trapret;
00132 
00133   sp -= sizeof *p->context;
00134   p->context = (struct context*)sp;
00135   memset(p->context, 0, sizeof *p->context);
00136   p->context->eip = (uint)forkret;
00137   return p;
00138 }

00140 // Set up first user process.
00141 void
00142 userinit(void)
00143 {
00144   struct proc *p;
00145   extern char _binary_initcode_start[], _binary_initcode_size[];
00146   
00147   p = allocproc();
00148   initproc = p;
00149 
00150   // Initialize memory from initcode.S
00151   p->sz = PAGE;
00152   p->mem = kalloc(p->sz);
00153   memset(p->mem, 0, p->sz);
00154   memmove(p->mem, _binary_initcode_start, (int)_binary_initcode_size);
00155 
00156   memset(p->tf, 0, sizeof(*p->tf));
00157   p->tf->cs = (SEG_UCODE << 3) | DPL_USER;
00158   p->tf->ds = (SEG_UDATA << 3) | DPL_USER;
00159   p->tf->es = p->tf->ds;
00160   p->tf->ss = p->tf->ds;
00161   p->tf->eflags = FL_IF;
00162   p->tf->esp = p->sz;
00163   p->tf->eip = 0;  // beginning of initcode.S
00164 
00165   safestrcpy(p->name, "initcode", sizeof(p->name));
00166   p->cwd = namei("/");
00167 
00168   p->state = RUNNABLE;
00169 }
00170 
00171 // Grow current process's memory by n bytes.
00172 // Return 0 on success, -1 on failure.
00173 int
00174 growproc(int n)
00175 {
00176   char *newmem;
00177 
00178   newmem = kalloc(proc->sz + n);
00179   if(newmem == 0)
00180     return -1;
00181   memmove(newmem, proc->mem, proc->sz);
00182   memset(newmem + proc->sz, 0, n);
00183   kfree(proc->mem, proc->sz);
00184   proc->mem = newmem;
00185   proc->sz += n;
00186   usegment();
00187   return 0;
00188 }
00189 
00190 // Create a new process copying p as the parent.
00191 // Sets up stack to return as if from system call.
00192 // Caller must set state of returned proc to RUNNABLE.
00193 int
00194 fork(void)
00195 {
00196   int i, pid;
00197   struct proc *np;
00198 
00199   // Allocate process.
00200   if((np = allocproc()) == 0)
00201     return -1;
00202 
00203   // Copy process state from p.
00204   np->sz = proc->sz;
00205   if((np->mem = kalloc(np->sz)) == 0){
00206     kfree(np->kstack, KSTACKSIZE);
00207     np->kstack = 0;
00208     np->state = UNUSED;
00209     return -1;
00210   }
00211   memmove(np->mem, proc->mem, np->sz);
00212   np->parent = proc;
00213   *np->tf = *proc->tf;
00214 
00215   // Clear %eax so that fork returns 0 in the child.
00216   np->tf->eax = 0;
00217 
00218   for(i = 0; i < NOFILE; i++)
00219     if(proc->ofile[i])
00220       np->ofile[i] = filedup(proc->ofile[i]);
00221   np->cwd = idup(proc->cwd);
00222  
00223   pid = np->pid;
00224   np->state = RUNNABLE;
00225 
00226   return pid;
00227 }
00228 
00229 // Per-CPU process scheduler.
00230 // Each CPU calls scheduler() after setting itself up.
00231 // Scheduler never returns.  It loops, doing:
00232 //  - choose a process to run
00233 //  - swtch to start running that process
00234 //  - eventually that process transfers control
00235 //      via swtch back to the scheduler.
00236 void
00237 scheduler(void)
00238 {
00239   struct proc *p;
00240 
00241   for(;;){
00242     // Enable interrupts on this processor.
00243     sti();
00244 
00245     // Loop over process table looking for process to run.
00246     acquire(&ptable.lock);
00247     for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++){
00248       if(p->state != RUNNABLE)
00249         continue;
00250 
00251       // Switch to chosen process.  It is the process's job
00252       // to release ptable.lock and then reacquire it
00253       // before jumping back to us.
00254       proc = p;
00255       usegment();
00256       p->state = RUNNING;
00257       swtch(&cpu->scheduler, proc->context);
00258 
00259       // Process is done running for now.
00260       // It should have changed its p->state before coming back.
00261       proc = 0;
00262     }
00263     release(&ptable.lock);
00264 
00265   }
00266 }
00267 
00268 // Enter scheduler.  Must hold only ptable.lock
00269 // and have changed proc->state.
00270 void
00271 sched(void)
00272 {
00273   int intena;
00274 
00275   if(!holding(&ptable.lock))
00276     panic("sched ptable.lock");
00277   if(cpu->ncli != 1)
00278     panic("sched locks");
00279   if(proc->state == RUNNING)
00280     panic("sched running");
00281   if(readeflags()&FL_IF)
00282     panic("sched interruptible");
00283 
00284   intena = cpu->intena;
00285   swtch(&proc->context, cpu->scheduler);
00286   cpu->intena = intena;
00287 }
00288 
00289 // Give up the CPU for one scheduling round.
00290 void
00291 yield(void)
00292 {
00293   acquire(&ptable.lock);  //DOC: yieldlock
00294   proc->state = RUNNABLE;
00295   sched();
00296   release(&ptable.lock);
00297 }
00298 
00299 // A fork child's very first scheduling by scheduler()
00300 // will swtch here.  "Return" to user space.
00301 void
00302 forkret(void)
00303 {
00304   // Still holding ptable.lock from scheduler.
00305   release(&ptable.lock);
00306   
00307   // Return to "caller", actually trapret (see allocproc).
00308 }
00309 
00310 // Atomically release lock and sleep on chan.
00311 // Reacquires lock when awakened.
00312 void
00313 sleep(void *chan, struct spinlock *lk)
00314 {
00315   if(proc == 0)
00316     panic("sleep");
00317 
00318   if(lk == 0)
00319     panic("sleep without lk");
00320 
00321   // Must acquire ptable.lock in order to
00322   // change p->state and then call sched.
00323   // Once we hold ptable.lock, we can be
00324   // guaranteed that we won't miss any wakeup
00325   // (wakeup runs with ptable.lock locked),
00326   // so it's okay to release lk.
00327   if(lk != &ptable.lock){  //DOC: sleeplock0
00328     acquire(&ptable.lock);  //DOC: sleeplock1
00329     release(lk);
00330   }
00331 
00332   // Go to sleep.
00333   proc->chan = chan;
00334   proc->state = SLEEPING;
00335   sched();
00336 
00337   // Tidy up.
00338   proc->chan = 0;
00339 
00340   // Reacquire original lock.
00341   if(lk != &ptable.lock){  //DOC: sleeplock2
00342     release(&ptable.lock);
00343     acquire(lk);
00344   }
00345 }
00346 
00347 // Wake up all processes sleeping on chan.
00348 // The ptable lock must be held.
00349 static void
00350 wakeup1(void *chan)
00351 {
00352   struct proc *p;
00353 
00354   for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++)
00355     if(p->state == SLEEPING && p->chan == chan)
00356       p->state = RUNNABLE;
00357 }
00358 
00359 // Wake up all processes sleeping on chan.
00360 void
00361 wakeup(void *chan)
00362 {
00363   acquire(&ptable.lock);
00364   wakeup1(chan);
00365   release(&ptable.lock);
00366 }
00367 
00368 // Kill the process with the given pid.
00369 // Process won't exit until it returns
00370 // to user space (see trap in trap.c).
00371 int
00372 kill(int pid)
00373 {
00374   struct proc *p;
00375 
00376   acquire(&ptable.lock);
00377   for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++){
00378     if(p->pid == pid){
00379       p->killed = 1;
00380       // Wake process from sleep if necessary.
00381       if(p->state == SLEEPING)
00382         p->state = RUNNABLE;
00383       release(&ptable.lock);
00384       return 0;
00385     }
00386   }
00387   release(&ptable.lock);
00388   return -1;
00389 }
00390 
00391 // Exit the current process.  Does not return.
00392 // An exited process remains in the zombie state
00393 // until its parent calls wait() to find out it exited.
00394 void
00395 exit(void)
00396 {
00397   struct proc *p;
00398   int fd;
00399 
00400   if(proc == initproc)
00401     panic("init exiting");
00402 
00403   // Close all open files.
00404   for(fd = 0; fd < NOFILE; fd++){
00405     if(proc->ofile[fd]){
00406       fileclose(proc->ofile[fd]);
00407       proc->ofile[fd] = 0;
00408     }
00409   }
00410 
00411   iput(proc->cwd);
00412   proc->cwd = 0;
00413 
00414   acquire(&ptable.lock);
00415 
00416   // Parent might be sleeping in wait().
00417   wakeup1(proc->parent);
00418 
00419   // Pass abandoned children to init.
00420   for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++){
00421     if(p->parent == proc){
00422       p->parent = initproc;
00423       if(p->state == ZOMBIE)
00424         wakeup1(initproc);
00425     }
00426   }
00427 
00428   // Jump into the scheduler, never to return.
00429   proc->state = ZOMBIE;
00430   sched();
00431   panic("zombie exit");
00432 }
00433 
00434 // Wait for a child process to exit and return its pid.
00435 // Return -1 if this process has no children.
00436 int
00437 wait(void)
00438 {
00439   struct proc *p;
00440   int havekids, pid;
00441 
00442   acquire(&ptable.lock);
00443   for(;;){
00444     // Scan through table looking for zombie children.
00445     havekids = 0;
00446     for(p = ptable.proc; p < &ptable.proc[NPROC]; p++){
00447       if(p->parent != proc)
00448         continue;
00449       havekids = 1;
00450       if(p->state == ZOMBIE){
00451         // Found one.
00452         pid = p->pid;
00453         kfree(p->mem, p->sz);
00454         kfree(p->kstack, KSTACKSIZE);
00455         p->state = UNUSED;
00456         p->pid = 0;
00457         p->parent = 0;
00458         p->name[0] = 0;
00459         p->killed = 0;
00460         release(&ptable.lock);
00461         return pid;
00462       }
00463     }
00464 
00465     // No point waiting if we don't have any children.
00466     if(!havekids || proc->killed){
00467       release(&ptable.lock);
00468       return -1;
00469     }
00470 
00471     // Wait for children to exit.  (See wakeup1 call in proc_exit.)
00472     sleep(proc, &ptable.lock);  //DOC: wait-sleep
00473   }
00474 }
